posts.cooked:
@Peter_Johnson Just wondering if this camera is supported in the latest image:

A specialised camera for fast motion photography and machine vision applications

It uses a Sony IMX296 sensor

Thanks!

link_counts.title: Buy a Raspberry Pi Global Shutter Camera – Raspberry Pi
Reading rpi camera with rpi 4 and python

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Yes, it should, although you need to edit /boot/config.txt to load the appropriate imx296 driver overlay, as auto-detect doesn’t seem to work for V4L2.  We need to add info on how to do this to the docs.

Thanks for the input.

We updated the config.txt file to include the imx296.

SSH’ed into the Pi and ran “libcamera-hello --list-cameras” :

0 : imx296 [1456x1088] (/base/soc/i2c0mux/i2c@1/imx296@1a) Modes: ‘SRGGB10_CSI2P’ : 1456x1088 [60.38 fps - (0, 0)/1456x1088 crop]

Ran libcamera-still : captured a jpg, looked good

Ran libcamera-vid : captured an h264 encoded video, transferred the file to Windows, looked good

But when running the multi-camera streaming application, or our vision application (via uploaded Python file), we get tons of:

CS: ERROR: ioctl VIDIOC_QBUF failed at UsbCameraImpl.cpp:719: Invalid argument (UsbUtil.cpp:156) CS: WARNING: rPi Camera 0: could not queue buffer 0 (UsbCameraImpl.cpp:720)

Vision Settings says that the camera is connected, but when clicking on “Open Stream” we get:

USB device path: /dev/video0

Alternate device path: /dev/v4l/by-path/platform-fe801000.csi-video-index0

Supported Video Modes: (no modes show and no image is displayed)

We tried several camera settings (w, h, fps).

We are running the 64-bit version of the WPILibPi image, rev 2023.2.1.

What do you recommend as a next step? Are there any other utilities or tools that might help to determine what is happening here?

Thanks again for all your help!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: You have to set the resolution in the camera settings (in the web interface) to exactly the supported mode as reported by libcamera.  The V4L2 compatibility layer is really terrible for MIPI cameras now and we don’t have libcamera support implemented.

@Peter_Johnson We set the w, h and fps exactly as reported by libcamera-hello --list-cameras and still saw the same errors with Pi GS camera.

Here is our config.txt:

#hdmi_safe=1

#overscan_left=16 #overscan_right=16 #overscan_top=16 #overscan_bottom=16

#framebuffer_width=1280 #framebuffer_height=720

#hdmi_force_hotplug=1

#hdmi_group=1 #hdmi_mode=1

#hdmi_drive=2

#config_hdmi_boost=4

#sdtv_mode=2

#uncomment to overclock the arm. 700 MHz is the default. #arm_freq=800

#dtparam=i2c_arm=on #dtparam=i2s=on #dtparam=spi=on

#dtoverlay=gpio-ir,gpio_pin=17 #dtoverlay=gpio-ir-tx,gpio_pin=18

dtparam=audio=on

#camera_auto_detect=1 gpu_mem=128 disable_camera_led=1

#camera_auto_detect=1

camera_auto_detect=0 #dtoverlay=imx219,media-controller=0 #dtoverlay=imx290,clock-frequency=74250000,media-controller=0 #dtoverlay=imx290,clock-frequency=37125000,media-controller=0 #dtoverlay=imx378,media-controller=0 #dtoverlay=ov5647,media-controller=0 #dtoverlay=ov9281,media-controller=0 dtoverlay=imx296

display_auto_detect=1

dtoverlay=vc4-kms-v3d max_framebuffers=2

arm_64bit=1

disable_overscan=1

[cm4]

otg_mode=1

[all]

[pi4]

arm_boost=1

[all]

We have a Pi Camera 2, Pi HQ Camera and the Pi GS camera. So GS doesn’t seem to work, will Pi Camera or Pi HQ Camera work? Which of those require changes to config.txt? I think Pi Camera 2? Can you share the config for any of those that are known to work? I think you replied to another message about Pi Camera 2 to add the config, I will check that as well.

Thanks!

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Are you sure you’re on the latest kernel? Absent that, you could try replacing cscore with photon-libcamera-gl-driver, though you would need to recompile that against the latest libcamera with the new stuff for the global shutter camera.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Any MIPI camera requires changes to config.txt.  In addition to setting the resolution, you may need to change the pixel mode as well to something other than JPEG.  It’s also worth looking at the output from dmesg to see if it’s reporting any errors regarding what’s being requested.

Thanks to the suggestion from @Peter_Johnson , we replaced cscore for camera image capture in our vision processing code with the new version of PiCamera that is based on libcamera, and that worked! Thanks to all for your input!

posts.name: BillDunlap
posts.cooked:
Can you share the details (e.g., a github link) on how you changed the cscore-based code to use PiCamera?

-Bill

We have been running this code, that calls into Picamera2, on the WPILibPi image

from picamera2 import Picamera2 from libcamera import controls from cscore import CameraServer

picam2 = Picamera2()

picam2_config = picam2.create_still_configuration( {‘size’: (w, h), ‘format’ : ‘RGB888’} ) picam2.configure(picam2_config) picam2.start()

time.sleep(3)

print(picam2_config[“main”])

while True:

You can still use cscore to output image to set it on SmartDashboard / Shuffleboard. Picamera2 doesn’t change that. So you would add to init: outputStream = CameraServer.putVideo(“image”, w, h)

and in your image processing loop, you would just do: outputStream.putFrame(img) # send to dashboard

picamera2-image-capture.py (924 Bytes) My apologies for the mess of the last post.

I put the code into a file and attached it to this reply.

link_counts.title: Reading rpi camera with rpi 4 and python

posts.name: BillDunlap
posts.cooked:
Thank you.  I had thought one needed to stop using cscore altogether, but I see that it is still can be used for sending the picture captured by the Picamera2 code to the smart dashboard.

-Bill
